title: Attribute
data:
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [ ]## Contents* [1 Strength](#Strength)

* [2 Dexterity](#Dexterity)

* [3 Constitution](#Constitution)

* [4 Intelligence](#Intelligence)

* [5 Wisdom](#Wisdom)

* [6 Charisma](#Charisma)

* [7 Starting attributes](#Starting_attributes)

* [8 Maximum attributes](#Maximum_attributes)

* [9 Variants](#Variants)

  - [9.1 NetHack brass](#NetHack_brass)
    - [9.1.1 Racial modifiers](#Racial_modifiers)

  - [9.2 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)

    - [9.2.1 Strength](#Strength_2)
    - [9.2.2 Dexterity](#Dexterity_2)

An **attribute** shows some capability of the player. Alternatively, "attribute" may refer to [properties](/wiki/Property "Property") divined through [enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment "Enlightenment") or [death](/wiki/Death "Death").

There are six basic attributes, as in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*. Four of a player's attributes can be increased by [exercising](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise") them.

## Strength

- *Main article: [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength")*

**Strength** corresponds to the ability to have more [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") in [your](/wiki/You "You") [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory"). Also, the stronger you are, the more damage you do in melee combat, and the farther you can [throw](/wiki/Throw "Throw") objects.

## Dexterity

- *Main article: [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity")*

**Dexterity** has a multitude of effects, of which the most significant is probably that it affects your chance of hitting monsters, whether in melee combat or with a missile or spell.

## Constitution

- *Main article: [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution")*

Having a high **constitution** increases your healing rate and the number of [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") you gain when levelling up and allows you to carry more [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") in your [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory").

## Intelligence

**Intelligence** is useful for [reading](/wiki/Read "Read") [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook"), for [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") (unless you are a [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") or [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), in which case it is wisdom that affects your chances of successfully casting a spell) and for encounters with [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi"). [Mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") have a brain-eating attack that can drain your intelligence; if you are hit by a successful brain-eating attack when your base intelligence is already 3, you die of [brainlessness](/wiki/Brainlessness "Brainlessness").

Intelligence cannot be [exercised](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise"), but can be permanently increased by drinking a blessed [potion of enlightenment](/wiki/Potion_of_enlightenment "Potion of enlightenment") or a [potion of gain ability](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_ability "Potion of gain ability"). It can also be temporarily increased by wearing a [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance"). If you eat a mind flayer corpse, there is a 50% chance your intelligence will be permanently increased by one point.

## Wisdom

- *Main article: [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom")*

A Healer, Knight, Monk, Priest or Valkyrie requires **wisdom** to cast [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell"). Wisdom is not particularly important for most other classes, though it affects how fast your [power](/wiki/Power "Power") regenerates (and is thus fairly important for [wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")) and how much power you gain when leveling up.

## Charisma

**Charisma** is mostly useful for obtaining better prices at [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) It also helps with [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus") encounters, both by increasing the chance of a positive result and by giving more control over whether they remove your armor.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Charisma also has other effects:

- The chance of successfully [bribing demons](/wiki/Bribe#Bribing_in_Gehennom "Bribe") with less money than they demand.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)
- The amount of gold required to [bribe the Yendorian army](/wiki/Bribe#Bribing_the_Yendorian_Army "Bribe").[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)
- The chance of successfully applying a [saddle](/wiki/Saddle "Saddle") to a monster.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)
- The initial [apport](/wiki/Apport "Apport") of new pets is equal to your charisma.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)
- Several [messages](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM") that don't affect game mechanics.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Charisma affects the probability that monsters are affected by [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict").

Charisma is a difficult stat to increase, as it cannot be exercised. It can be permanently increased by drinking a [potion of gain ability](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_ability "Potion of gain ability"), or temporarily increased by wearing a charged [ring of adornment](/wiki/Ring_of_adornment "Ring of adornment"). You can also gain charisma by triggering a [magic trap](/wiki/Magic_trap "Magic trap"); however, this can be dangerous.

| Charisma | Price |
| -------- | ----- |
| 3–5      | ×2    |
| 6–7      | ×1.5  |
| 8–10     | ×1.33 |
| 11–15    | ×1    |
| 16–17    | ×0.75 |
| 18       | ×0.67 |
| 19–25    | ×0.5  |

Reference: [shk.c, line 1910](/wiki/Source:Shk.c#line1910 "Source:Shk.c").

## Starting attributes

The player's starting attributes depend on their [role](/wiki/Role "Role") as follows:[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

| Class                                             | [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") | Remaining |
| ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | --------- |
| [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") | 7\20%                                 | 7\10%                                    | 7\20%                                             | 10\20%                                            | 10\20%                          | 7\10%                                 | 27        |
| [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian")          | 16\30%                                | 15\20%                                   | 16\30%                                            | 7\6%                                              | 7\7%                            | 6\7%                                  | 8         |
| [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman")                | 10\30%                                | 7\20%                                    | 8\30%                                             | 7\6%                                              | 7\7%                            | 6\7%                                  | 30        |
| [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer")                   | 7\15%                                 | 7\15%                                    | 11\25%                                            | 7\20%                                             | 13\20%                          | 16\5%                                 | 14        |
| [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                   | 13\30%                                | 8\10%                                    | 10\20%                                            | 7\15%                                             | 14\15%                          | 17\10%                                | 6         |
| [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk")                         | 10\25%                                | 8\20%                                    | 7\15%                                             | 7\10%                                             | 8\20%                           | 7\10%                                 | 28        |
| [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                   | 7\15%                                 | 7\15%                                    | 7\20%                                             | 7\10%                                             | 10\30%                          | 7\10%                                 | 30        |
| [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                   | 13\30%                                | 9\20%                                    | 13\20%                                            | 13\10%                                            | 13\10%                          | 7\10%                                 | 7         |
| [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                      | 7\20%                                 | 10\30%                                   | 7\20%                                             | 7\10%                                             | 7\10%                           | 6\10%                                 | 31        |
| [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")                | 10\30%                                | 10\30%                                   | 17\14%                                            | 8\10%                                             | 7\8%                            | 6\8%                                  | 17        |
| [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")                | 7\15%                                 | 7\15%                                    | 7\30%                                             | 10\10%                                            | 6\10%                           | 10\20%                                | 28        |
| [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie")             | 10\30%                                | 7\20%                                    | 10\30%                                            | 7\6%                                              | 7\7%                            | 7\7%                                  | 27        |
| [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                   | 7\10%                                 | 7\20%                                    | 7\20%                                             | 10\30%                                            | 7\10%                           | 7\10%                                 | 30        |

First, points are distributed so that the player receives, as a minimum, the number indicated before the backslash. This is always out of a pool of 75 points, and the Remaining column contains the amount of leftover points from this step.

Next, the remaining points are distributed randomly according to the percentage after the backslash. If an attribute is chosen that would raise it above the player's racial maximum, it will try 99 more times to choose a different attribute to raise. If it fails to pick an attribute on all 100 attempts, it will abort this step and any remaining points will be lost.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

Third, each attribute has a 5% probability of having a random number from −2 to +4 added to it [\[12\]](#cite_note-12). These respect racial maximums.

Finally, strength will, if necessary, be increased until the player is [unencumbered](/wiki/Encumbrance "Encumbrance") by their starting inventory. If their racial maximum is not enough, constitution will be increased similarly.

## Maximum attributes

The player's maximum attributes depend on their [race](/wiki/Race "Race") as follows:[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)

| [Race](/wiki/Race "Race")                                      | Strength | Dexterity | Constitution | Intelligence | Wisdom | Charisma |
| -------------------------------------------------------------- | -------- | --------- | ------------ | ------------ | ------ | -------- |
| [Human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)") | 18/\*\*  | 18        | 18           | 18           | 18     | 18       |
| [Elf](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)")       | 18       | 18        | 16           | 20           | 20     | 18       |
| [Dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") | 18/\*\*  | 20        | 20           | 16           | 16     | 16       |
| [Gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") | 18/50    | 18        | 18           | 19           | 18     | 18       |
| [Orc](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)")       | 18/50    | 18        | 18           | 16           | 16     | 16       |

These maxima only apply to your base "naked" attributes. Some magic items, like the [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance"), [gauntlets of power](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_power "Gauntlets of power") and [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity"), allow you to exceed these limits, up to 25 for all attributes. All attributes have a minimum of 3.

## Variants

### NetHack brass

[NetHack brass](/wiki/NetHack_brass "NetHack brass") implements different maximum attributes per role. Find your maximum attributes by looking for your role in the next table, then applying the racial modifiers. For example, humans have +2 to strength. All [heroes](/wiki/Hero "Hero") have a minimum of 3 for each attribute. The entries with the exclamation marks are the spellcasting stats for each role.

| [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                         | Strength | Dexterity | Constitution | Intelligence | Wisdom | Charisma |
| ------------------------------------------------- | -------- | --------- | ------------ | ------------ | ------ | -------- |
| [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") | 16       | 10        | 17           | *19!*        | 18     | 19       |
| [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian")          | 18/\*\*  | 18        | 20           | *12!*        | 16     | 10       |
| [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman")                | 18/\*\*  | 18        | 20           | *14!*        | 16     | 15       |
| [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer")                   | 12       | 19        | 19           | 19           | *19!*  | 18       |
| [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                   | 18/50    | 13        | 18           | 17           | *19!*  | 19       |
| [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk")                         | 10       | 20        | 20           | 18           | *20!*  | 18       |
| [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                   | 18       | 15        | 18           | 17           | *20!*  | 18       |
| [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                   | 17       | 21        | 13           | *19!*        | 16     | 19       |
| [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                      | 18       | 20        | 17           | *17!*        | 17     | 16       |
| [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")                | 18/50    | 20        | 19           | *15!*        | 15     | 15       |
| [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")                | 17       | 15        | 18           | *19!*        | 19     | 19       |
| [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie")             | 18/\*\*  | 16        | 20           | 12           | *17!*  | 16       |
| [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                   | 10       | 19        | 16           | *20!*        | 20     | 18       |

Reference: src/role.c in NetHack brass 040923.

#### Racial modifiers

To find your maximum attributes in [NetHack brass](/wiki/NetHack_brass "NetHack brass"), after finding your role in the above table, you must apply the racial modifiers of the below table. These racial modifiers apply only to the *maximum* attributes of each player, not the initial attributes.

An elven Ranger of NetHack brass, for example, can reach 19+1 = 20 in charisma by increasing charisma one more time after a human Ranger would have maxed at 19.

For strength modifiers only, a +1 raises 18 to 18/50, while a +2 raises 18 to 18/\*\* or 17 to 18/50.

| [Race](/wiki/Race "Race")                                      | Strength | Dexterity | Constitution | Intelligence | Wisdom | Charisma |
| -------------------------------------------------------------- | -------- | --------- | ------------ | ------------ | ------ | -------- |
| [Human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)") | +2       | 0         | 0            | 0            | 0      | 0        |
| [Elf](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)")       | 0        | 0         | −2           | +2           | +2     | +1       |
| [Dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") | +2       | +2        | +2           | −2           | −2     | −2       |
| [Gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") | +1       | 0         | 0            | +1           | 0      | 0        |
| [Orc](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)")       | +2       | 0         | 0            | −2           | −2     | −3       |

In [wizard mode](/wiki/Wizard_mode "Wizard mode"), the #[rrllududab](/wiki/Rrllududab "Rrllududab") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") sets your attributes to their maximum; this is a reference to the [Konami code](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konami_code "wikipedia:Konami code").

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") handles several attributes differently compared to *NetHack*.

#### Strength

Due to the changed behavior of the [gauntlets of power](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_power "Gauntlets of power"), strength between 18/\*\* and 25 is handled differently. Strength grants bonuses to damage and to-hit as follows:

| strength    | to-hit | damage |
| ----------- | ------ | ------ |
| 3–5         | −2     | −1     |
| 6–7         | −1     | 0      |
| 8–15        | 0      | 0      |
| 16          | 0      | +1     |
| 17          | +1     | +1     |
| 18          | +1     | +2     |
| 18/01–18/99 | +1     | +3     |
| 18/\*\*     | +2     | +4     |
| 19          | +2     | +5     |
| 20          | +3     | +6     |
| 21          | +3     | +7     |
| 22          | +4     | +8     |
| 23          | +4     | +9     |
| 24          | +5     | +10    |
| 25          | +5     | +11    |

Reference: [weapon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 900](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/weapon.c#line900 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/weapon.c").

#### Dexterity

Dexterity now has an impact on AC, and higher Dexterity provides bonuses to AC.

| dexterity | AC |
| --------- | -- |
| 3<        | +3 |
| 4–5       | +2 |
| 6–7       | +1 |
| 8–14      | 0  |
| 15        | −1 |
| 16        | −2 |
| 17        | −3 |
| 18        | −4 |
| 19        | −5 |
| 20–21     | −6 |
| 22–23     | −7 |
| >23       | −8 |

### UnNetHack

[UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") adds the ability to exercise intelligence by fighting a [weeping angel](/wiki/Weeping_angel "Weeping angel")'s mental reflection, which requires that the player does *not* have [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection").[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), strength over 18 is no longer considered a special attribute, and "exceptional strength" of 18/XX does not exist - their numeric equivalents are used instead, as follows:

- [Elves](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)"): 18
- [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)"): 19
- [Orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)"): 20
- [Humans](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"): 21
- [Dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)"): 21

## See also

- [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points")
- [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory")
- [purse](/wiki/Purse "Purse")
- [encumbrance](/wiki/Encumbrance "Encumbrance")
- [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight")
- [intrinsic](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic")
- [Drain for gain](/wiki/Drain_for_gain "Drain for gain"), which involves manipulating your attributes, and discusses how to do so.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/shk.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2134](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/shk.c#L2134)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2431](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/mhitu.c#L2431)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/minion.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 304](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/minion.c#L304)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/dokick.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 372](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/dokick.c#L372)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/steed.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 94](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/steed.c#L94)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 45](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/dog.c#L45)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/dig.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1362](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/dig.c#L1362)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 826](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/apply.c#L826)
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 751](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/eat.c#L751)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [src/role.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 54](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/role.c#L54): *base attributes and distributions*
11. [↑](#cite_ref-11) [attrib.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 565](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/attrib.c#L565)
12. [↑](#cite_ref-12) [u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 884](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/u_init.c#L884)
13. [↑](#cite_ref-13) [role.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 405](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/role.c#line405 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/role.c")
14. [↑](#cite_ref-14) <https://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/git/ci/master/tree/src/mhitu.c#l2206>

html:
Attribute

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Contents

  • 1 Strength
  • 2 Dexterity
  • 3 Constitution
  • 4 Intelligence
  • 5 Wisdom
  • 6 Charisma
  • 7 Starting attributes
  • 8 Maximum attributes
  • 9 Variants
    • 9.1 NetHack brass
      • 9.1.1 Racial modifiers
    • 9.2 SLASH'EM
      • 9.2.1 Strength
      • 9.2.2 Dexterity
    • 9.3 UnNetHack
    • 9.4 FIQHack
  • 10 See also
  • 11 References

An attribute shows some capability of the player. Alternatively, "attribute" may refer to properties divined through enlightenment or death.

There are six basic attributes, as in Dungeons & Dragons. Four of a player's attributes can be increased by exercising them.

Strength

Main article: Strength

Strength corresponds to the ability to have more weight in your inventory. Also, the stronger you are, the more damage you do in melee combat, and the farther you can throw objects.

Dexterity

Main article: Dexterity

Dexterity has a multitude of effects, of which the most significant is probably that it affects your chance of hitting monsters, whether in melee combat or with a missile or spell.

Constitution

Main article: Constitution

Having a high constitution increases your healing rate and the number of HP you gain when levelling up and allows you to carry more weight in your inventory.

Intelligence

Intelligence is useful for reading spellbooks, for spellcasting (unless you are a Healer, Knight, Monk, Priest or Valkyrie, in which case it is wisdom that affects your chances of successfully casting a spell) and for encounters with foocubi. Mind flayers have a brain-eating attack that can drain your intelligence; if you are hit by a successful brain-eating attack when your base intelligence is already 3, you die of brainlessness.

Intelligence cannot be exercised, but can be permanently increased by drinking a blessed potion of enlightenment or a potion of gain ability. It can also be temporarily increased by wearing a helm of brilliance. If you eat a mind flayer corpse, there is a 50% chance your intelligence will be permanently increased by one point.

Wisdom

Main article: Wisdom

A Healer, Knight, Monk, Priest or Valkyrie requires wisdom to cast spells. Wisdom is not particularly important for most other classes, though it affects how fast your power regenerates (and is thus fairly important for wizards) and how much power you gain when leveling up.

Charisma

Charisma is mostly useful for obtaining better prices at shops.[1] It also helps with foocubus encounters, both by increasing the chance of a positive result and by giving more control over whether they remove your armor.[2]

Charisma also has other effects:

  • The chance of successfully bribing demons with less money than they demand.[3]
  • The amount of gold required to bribe the Yendorian army.[4]
  • The chance of successfully applying a saddle to a monster.[5]
  • The initial apport of new pets is equal to your charisma.[6]
  • Several messages that don't affect game mechanics.[7][8][9]

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Charisma affects the probability that monsters are affected by conflict.

Charisma is a difficult stat to increase, as it cannot be exercised. It can be permanently increased by drinking a potion of gain ability, or temporarily increased by wearing a charged ring of adornment. You can also gain charisma by triggering a magic trap; however, this can be dangerous.

Charisma Price
3–5 ×2
6–7 ×1.5
8–10 ×1.33
11–15 ×1
16–17 ×0.75
18 ×0.67
19–25 ×0.5

Reference: shk.c, line 1910.

Starting attributes

The player's starting attributes depend on their role as follows:[10]

Class Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma Remaining
Archeologist 7\20% 7\10% 7\20% 10\20% 10\20% 7\10% 27
Barbarian 16\30% 15\20% 16\30% 7\6% 7\7% 6\7% 8
Caveman 10\30% 7\20% 8\30% 7\6% 7\7% 6\7% 30
Healer 7\15% 7\15% 11\25% 7\20% 13\20% 16\5% 14
Knight 13\30% 8\10% 10\20% 7\15% 14\15% 17\10% 6
Monk 10\25% 8\20% 7\15% 7\10% 8\20% 7\10% 28
Priest 7\15% 7\15% 7\20% 7\10% 10\30% 7\10% 30
Ranger 13\30% 9\20% 13\20% 13\10% 13\10% 7\10% 7
Rogue 7\20% 10\30% 7\20% 7\10% 7\10% 6\10% 31
Samurai 10\30% 10\30% 17\14% 8\10% 7\8% 6\8% 17
Tourist 7\15% 7\15% 7\30% 10\10% 6\10% 10\20% 28
Valkyrie 10\30% 7\20% 10\30% 7\6% 7\7% 7\7% 27
Wizard 7\10% 7\20% 7\20% 10\30% 7\10% 7\10% 30

First, points are distributed so that the player receives, as a minimum, the number indicated before the backslash. This is always out of a pool of 75 points, and the Remaining column contains the amount of leftover points from this step.

Next, the remaining points are distributed randomly according to the percentage after the backslash. If an attribute is chosen that would raise it above the player's racial maximum, it will try 99 more times to choose a different attribute to raise. If it fails to pick an attribute on all 100 attempts, it will abort this step and any remaining points will be lost.[11]

Third, each attribute has a 5% probability of having a random number from −2 to +4 added to it [12]. These respect racial maximums.

Finally, strength will, if necessary, be increased until the player is unencumbered by their starting inventory. If their racial maximum is not enough, constitution will be increased similarly.

Maximum attributes

The player's maximum attributes depend on their race as follows:[13]

Race Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma
Human 18/** 18 18 18 18 18
Elf 18 18 16 20 20 18
Dwarf 18/** 20 20 16 16 16
Gnome 18/50 18 18 19 18 18
Orc 18/50 18 18 16 16 16

These maxima only apply to your base "naked" attributes. Some magic items, like the helm of brilliance, gauntlets of power and gauntlets of dexterity, allow you to exceed these limits, up to 25 for all attributes. All attributes have a minimum of 3.

Variants

NetHack brass

NetHack brass implements different maximum attributes per role. Find your maximum attributes by looking for your role in the next table, then applying the racial modifiers. For example, humans have +2 to strength. All heroes have a minimum of 3 for each attribute. The entries with the exclamation marks are the spellcasting stats for each role.

Role Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma
Archeologist 16 10 17 19! 18 19
Barbarian 18/** 18 20 12! 16 10
Caveman 18/** 18 20 14! 16 15
Healer 12 19 19 19 19! 18
Knight 18/50 13 18 17 19! 19
Monk 10 20 20 18 20! 18
Priest 18 15 18 17 20! 18
Ranger 17 21 13 19! 16 19
Rogue 18 20 17 17! 17 16
Samurai 18/50 20 19 15! 15 15
Tourist 17 15 18 19! 19 19
Valkyrie 18/** 16 20 12 17! 16
Wizard 10 19 16 20! 20 18

Reference: src/role.c in NetHack brass 040923.

Racial modifiers

To find your maximum attributes in NetHack brass, after finding your role in the above table, you must apply the racial modifiers of the below table. These racial modifiers apply only to the maximum attributes of each player, not the initial attributes.

An elven Ranger of NetHack brass, for example, can reach 19+1 = 20 in charisma by increasing charisma one more time after a human Ranger would have maxed at 19.

For strength modifiers only, a +1 raises 18 to 18/50, while a +2 raises 18 to 18/** or 17 to 18/50.

Race Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma
Human +2 0 0 0 0 0
Elf 0 0 −2 +2 +2 +1
Dwarf +2 +2 +2 −2 −2 −2
Gnome +1 0 0 +1 0 0
Orc +2 0 0 −2 −2 −3

In wizard mode, the #rrllududab extended command sets your attributes to their maximum; this is a reference to the Konami code.

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM handles several attributes differently compared to NetHack.

Strength

Due to the changed behavior of the gauntlets of power, strength between 18/** and 25 is handled differently. Strength grants bonuses to damage and to-hit as follows:

strength to-hit damage
3–5 −2 −1
6–7 −1 0
8–15 0 0
16 0 +1
17 +1 +1
18 +1 +2
18/01–18/99 +1 +3
18/** +2 +4
19 +2 +5
20 +3 +6
21 +3 +7
22 +4 +8
23 +4 +9
24 +5 +10
25 +5 +11

Reference: weapon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 900.

Dexterity

Dexterity now has an impact on AC, and higher Dexterity provides bonuses to AC.

dexterity AC
3< +3
4–5 +2
6–7 +1
8–14 0
15 −1
16 −2
17 −3
18 −4
19 −5
20–21 −6
22–23 −7
>23 −8

UnNetHack

UnNetHack adds the ability to exercise intelligence by fighting a weeping angel's mental reflection, which requires that the player does not have reflection.[14]

FIQHack

In FIQHack, strength over 18 is no longer considered a special attribute, and "exceptional strength" of 18/XX does not exist - their numeric equivalents are used instead, as follows:

  • Elves: 18
  • Gnomes: 19
  • Orcs: 20
  • Humans: 21
  • Dwarves: 21

See also

  • hit points
  • inventory
  • purse
  • encumbrance
  • weight
  • intrinsic
  • Drain for gain, which involves manipulating your attributes, and discusses how to do so.

References

  4. ↑ src/dokick.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 372
  5. ↑ src/steed.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 94
  6. ↑ src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 45

  8. ↑ src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 826
  9. ↑ src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 751
  10. ↑ src/role.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 54: base attributes and distributions
  11. ↑ attrib.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 565
  12. ↑ u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 884
  13. ↑ role.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 405
  14. ↑ https://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/git/ci/master/tree/src/mhitu.c#l2206

rawPage:
{{tocright}}
An '''attribute''' shows some capability of the player. Alternatively, "attribute" may refer to [[property|properties]] divined through [[enlightenment]] or [[death]].

There are six basic attributes, as in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''. Four of a player's attributes can be increased by [[Exercise|exercising]] them.

==Strength==
{{main|Strength}}
'''Strength''' corresponds to the ability to have more [[weight]] in [[you]]r [[inventory]]. Also, the stronger you are, the more damage you do in melee combat, and the farther you can [[throw]] objects.

==Dexterity==
{{main|Dexterity}}
'''Dexterity''' has a multitude of effects, of which the most significant is probably that it affects your chance of hitting monsters, whether in melee combat or with a missile or spell.

==Constitution==
{{main|Constitution}}
Having a high '''constitution''' increases your healing rate and the number of [[HP]] you gain when levelling up and allows you to carry more [[weight]] in your [[inventory]].

==Intelligence==
'''Intelligence''' is useful for [[read]]ing [[spellbook]]s, for [[spellcasting]] (unless you are a [[Healer]], [[Knight]], [[Monk]], [[Priest]] or [[Valkyrie]], in which case it is wisdom that affects your chances of successfully casting a spell) and for encounters with [[foocubi]]. [[Mind flayer]]s have a brain-eating attack that can drain your intelligence; if you are hit by a successful brain-eating attack when your base intelligence is already 3, you die of [[brainlessness]].

Intelligence cannot be [[exercise]]d, but can be permanently increased by drinking a blessed [[potion of enlightenment]] or a [[potion of gain ability]]. It can also be temporarily increased by wearing a [[helm of brilliance]]. If you eat a mind flayer corpse, there is a 50% chance your intelligence will be permanently increased by one point.

==Wisdom==
{{main|Wisdom}}
A Healer, Knight, Monk, Priest or Valkyrie requires '''wisdom''' to cast [[spell]]s. Wisdom is not particularly important for most other classes, though it affects how fast your [[power]] regenerates (and is thus fairly important for [[wizard]]s) and how much power you gain when leveling up.

==Charisma==
'''Charisma''' is mostly useful for obtaining better prices at [[shop]]s.{{refsrc|src/shk.c|2134|nethack=3.6.6}} It also helps with [[foocubus]] encounters, both by increasing the chance of a positive result and by giving more control over whether they remove your armor.{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|2431|nethack=3.6.6}}

Charisma also has other effects:
* The chance of successfully [[bribe#Bribing_in_Gehennom|bribing demons]] with less money than they demand.{{refsrc|src/minion.c|304|nethack=3.6.6}}
* The amount of gold required to [[bribe#Bribing_the_Yendorian_Army|bribe the Yendorian army]].{{refsrc|src/dokick.c|372|nethack=3.6.6}}
* The chance of successfully applying a [[saddle]] to a monster.{{refsrc|src/steed.c|94|nethack=3.6.6}}
* The initial [[apport]] of new pets is equal to your charisma.{{refsrc|src/dog.c|45|nethack=3.6.6}}
* Several [[YAFM|messages]] that don't affect game mechanics.{{refsrc|src/dig.c|1362|nethack=3.6.6}}{{refsrc|src/apply.c|826|nethack=3.6.6}}{{refsrc|src/eat.c|751|nethack=3.6.6}}

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Charisma affects the probability that monsters are affected by [[conflict]].}}

Charisma is a difficult stat to increase, as it cannot be exercised. It can be permanently increased by drinking a [[potion of gain ability]], or temporarily increased by wearing a charged [[ring of adornment]]. You can also gain charisma by triggering a [[magic trap]]; however, this can be dangerous.

{| class="prettytable striped" 
!| Charisma
!| Price 
|- 
|| 3–5 || ×2 
|-
|| 6–7 || ×1.5
|-
|| 8–10 || ×1.33
|-
|| 11–15 || ×1
|-
|| 16–17 || ×0.75
|-
|| 18 || ×0.67
|-
|| 19–25 || ×0.5
|}
Reference: {{sourcecode|shk.c|1910}}.

==Starting attributes==
The player's starting attributes depend on their [[role]] as follows:{{refsrc|src/role.c|54|nethack=3.6.6|comment=base attributes and distributions}}

{| class="prettytable"
!| Class || [[Strength]] ||  [[Dexterity]] || [[Constitution]] ||[[Intelligence]] || [[Wisdom]] || [[Charisma]] || Remaining
|-
| [[Archeologist]] || 7\20% || 7\10% || 7\20% || 10\20% || 10\20% || 7\10% || 27
|-
| [[Barbarian]] || 16\30% || 15\20% || 16\30% || 7\6% || 7\7% || 6\7% || 8
|-
| [[Caveman]] || 10\30% || 7\20% || 8\30% || 7\6% || 7\7% || 6\7% || 30
|-
| [[Healer]] || 7\15% || 7\15% || 11\25% || 7\20% || 13\20% || 16\5% || 14
|-
| [[Knight]] || 13\30% || 8\10% || 10\20% || 7\15% || 14\15% || 17\10% || 6
|-
| [[Monk]] || 10\25% || 8\20% || 7\15% || 7\10% || 8\20% || 7\10% || 28
|-
| [[Priest]] || 7\15% || 7\15% || 7\20% || 7\10% || 10\30% || 7\10% || 30
|-
| [[Ranger]] || 13\30% || 9\20% || 13\20% || 13\10% || 13\10% || 7\10% || 7
|-
| [[Rogue]] || 7\20% || 10\30% || 7\20% || 7\10% || 7\10% || 6\10% || 31
|-
| [[Samurai]] || 10\30% || 10\30% || 17\14% || 8\10% || 7\8% || 6\8% || 17
|-
| [[Tourist]] || 7\15% || 7\15% || 7\30% || 10\10% || 6\10% || 10\20% || 28
|-
| [[Valkyrie]] || 10\30% || 7\20% || 10\30% || 7\6% || 7\7% || 7\7% || 27
|-
| [[Wizard]] || 7\10% || 7\20% || 7\20% || 10\30% || 7\10% || 7\10% || 30
|}

First, points are distributed so that the player receives, as a minimum, the number indicated before the backslash. This is always out of a pool of 75 points, and the Remaining column contains the amount of leftover points from this step.

Next, the remaining points are distributed randomly according to the percentage after the backslash. If an attribute is chosen that would raise it above the player's racial maximum, it will try 99 more times to choose a different attribute to raise. If it fails to pick an attribute on all 100 attempts, it will abort this step and any remaining points will be lost.{{refsrc|attrib.c|565|version=NetHack 3.6.0}}

Third, each attribute has a 5% probability of having a random number from −2 to +4 added to it {{refsrc|u_init.c|884|version=NetHack 3.6.0}}. These respect racial maximums.

Finally, strength will, if necessary, be increased until the player is [[Encumbrance|unencumbered]] by their starting inventory. If their racial maximum is not enough, constitution will be increased similarly.

==Maximum attributes==
The player's maximum attributes depend on their [[race]] as follows:{{refsrc|role.c|405}}
{| class="prettytable sortable striped"
!| [[Race]]
!| Strength
!| Dexterity
!| Constitution
!| Intelligence
!| Wisdom
!| Charisma
|-<!--                                St       Dx    Co    In    Wi    Ch -->
|| [[Human (starting race)|Human]] || 18/** || 18 || 18 || 18 || 18 || 18
|-
|| [[Elf (starting race)|Elf]]     || 18    || 18 || 16 || 20 || 20 || 18
|-
|| [[Dwarf (starting race)|Dwarf]] || 18/** || 20 || 20 || 16 || 16 || 16
|-
|| [[Gnome (starting race)|Gnome]] || 18/50 || 18 || 18 || 19 || 18 || 18
|-
|| [[Orc (starting race)|Orc]]     || 18/50 || 18 || 18 || 16 || 16 || 16
|}

These maxima only apply to your base "naked" attributes. Some magic items, like the [[helm of brilliance]], [[gauntlets of power]] and [[gauntlets of dexterity]], allow you to exceed these limits, up to 25 for all attributes. All attributes have a minimum of 3.

==Variants==
===NetHack brass===
[[NetHack brass]] implements different maximum attributes per role. Find your maximum attributes by looking for your role in the next table, then applying the racial modifiers. For example, humans have +2 to strength. All [[hero|heroes]] have a minimum of 3 for each attribute. The entries with the exclamation marks are the spellcasting stats for each role.

{| class="prettytable sortable striped"
!| [[Role]]
!| Strength
!| Dexterity
!| Constitution
!| Intelligence
!| Wisdom
!| Charisma
|-<!--                 St       Dx    Co    In        Wi    Ch -->
|| [[Archeologist]] || 16    || 10 || 17 || ''19!'' || 18 || 19
|-
|| [[Barbarian]]    || 18/** || 18 || 20 || ''12!'' || 16 || 10
|-
|| [[Caveman]]      || 18/** || 18 || 20 || ''14!'' || 16 || 15
|-
|| [[Healer]]       || 12    || 19 || 19 || 19 || ''19!'' || 18
|-
|| [[Knight]]       || 18/50 || 13 || 18 || 17 || ''19!'' || 19
|-
|| [[Monk]]         || 10    || 20 || 20 || 18 || ''20!'' || 18
|-
|| [[Priest]]       || 18    || 15 || 18 || 17 || ''20!'' || 18
|-
|| [[Ranger]]       || 17    || 21 || 13 || ''19!'' || 16 || 19
|-
|| [[Rogue]]        || 18    || 20 || 17 || ''17!'' || 17 || 16
|-
|| [[Samurai]]      || 18/50 || 20 || 19 || ''15!'' || 15 || 15
|-
|| [[Tourist]]      || 17    || 15 || 18 || ''19!'' || 19 || 19
|-
|| [[Valkyrie]]     || 18/** || 16 || 20 || 12 || ''17!'' || 16
|-
|| [[Wizard]]       || 10    || 19 || 16 || ''20!'' || 20 || 18
|}
Reference: src/role.c in NetHack brass 040923.

====Racial modifiers====
To find your maximum attributes in [[NetHack brass]], after finding your role in the above table, you must apply the racial modifiers of the below table. These racial modifiers apply only to the ''maximum'' attributes of each player, not the initial attributes.

An elven Ranger of NetHack brass, for example, can reach 19+1 = 20 in charisma by increasing charisma one more time after a human Ranger would have maxed at 19.

For strength modifiers only, a +1 raises 18 to 18/50, while a +2 raises 18 to 18/** or 17 to 18/50.

{| class="prettytable striped"
!| [[Race]]
!| Strength
!| Dexterity
!| Constitution
!| Intelligence
!| Wisdom
!| Charisma
|-<!--                                St    Dx    Co    In    Wi    Ch -->
|| [[Human (starting race)|Human]] || +2 ||  0 ||  0 ||  0 ||  0 ||  0
|-
|| [[Elf (starting race)|Elf]]     ||  0 ||  0 || −2 || +2 || +2 || +1
|-
|| [[Dwarf (starting race)|Dwarf]] || +2 || +2 || +2 || −2 || −2 || −2
|-
|| [[Gnome (starting race)|Gnome]] || +1 ||  0 ||  0 || +1 ||  0 ||  0
|-
|| [[Orc (starting race)|Orc]]     || +2 ||  0 ||  0 || −2 || −2 || −3
|}

In [[wizard mode]], the #[[rrllududab]] [[extended command]] sets your attributes to their maximum; this is a reference to the [[wikipedia:Konami code|Konami code]].

===SLASH'EM===
[[SLASH'EM]] handles several attributes differently compared to ''NetHack''.

====Strength====
Due to the changed behavior of the [[gauntlets of power]], strength between 18/** and 25 is handled differently. Strength grants bonuses to damage and to-hit as follows:

{| class="prettytable striped" 
!| strength 
!| to-hit 
!| damage
|- 
|| 3–5 || −2 || −1
|-
|| 6–7 || −1 || 0
|-
|| 8–15|| 0 || 0
|-
|| 16 || 0 || +1
|-
|| 17 || +1 || +1
|-
|| 18 || +1 || +2
|-
|| 18/01–18/99 || +1 || +3
|-
|| 18/** || +2 || +4
|-
|| 19 || +2 || +5
|-
|| 20 || +3 || +6
|-
|| 21 || +3 || +7
|-
|| 22 || +4 || +8
|-
|| 23 || +4 || +9
|-
|| 24 || +5 || +10
|-
|| 25 || +5 || +11
|}
Reference: {{sourcecode|weapon.c|900|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}.

====Dexterity====
Dexterity now has an impact on AC, and higher Dexterity provides bonuses to AC.

{| class="prettytable striped" 
!| dexterity 
!| AC
|- 
|| 3< || +3 
|-
|| 4–5 ||  +2
|-
|| 6–7 ||  +1
|-
|| 8–14 || 0
|-
|| 15 || −1
|-
|| 16 || −2
|-
|| 17 || −3
|-
|| 18 || −4
|-
|| 19 || −5
|-
|| 20–21 || −6
|-
|| 22–23 || −7
|-
|| >23 || −8
|}

===UnNetHack===
[[UnNetHack]] adds the ability to exercise intelligence by fighting a [[weeping angel]]'s mental reflection, which requires that the player does ''not'' have [[reflection]].<ref>https://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/git/ci/master/tree/src/mhitu.c#l2206</ref>

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], strength over 18 is no longer considered a special attribute, and "exceptional strength" of 18/XX does not exist - their numeric equivalents are used instead, as follows:

* [[Elf (starting race)|Elves]]: 18
* [[Gnome (starting race)|Gnomes]]: 19
* [[Orc (starting race)|Orcs]]: 20
* [[Human (starting race)|Humans]]: 21
* [[Dwarf (starting race)|Dwarves]]: 21
